.

## Reading and Examining the data




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
## Calling Data
frogs_orig <- read_delim(file ="../../Data/frogs.csv", delim = ",")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Rows: 60 Columns: 4
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
dbl (4): Frogspawn sample id, Temperature13, Temperature18, Temperature25

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
frogs_orig
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 60 × 4
   `Frogspawn sample id` Temperature13 Temperature18 Temperature25
                   <dbl>         <dbl>         <dbl>         <dbl>
 1                     1            24            NA            NA
 2                     2            NA            21            NA
 3                     3            NA            NA            18
 4                     4            26            NA            NA
 5                     5            NA            22            NA
 6                     6            NA            NA            14
 7                     7            27            NA            NA
 8                     8            NA            22            NA
 9                     9            NA            NA            15
10                    10            27            NA            NA
# ℹ 50 more rows
```


:::
:::




.




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
##Cleaning the Data
frogs_orig %>% 
  ##
  pivot_longer(
    .,
    cols = starts_with("Temperature"),
    cols_vary = "fastest",
    names_to = "Temp",
    values_to = "Time"
  ) %>% 
  ##
  drop_na() %>% 
  
  ## "\\d+" is regex language for 'keep only the digits'all digits'
  
  separate_wider_regex(
    cols = Temp,
    patterns = c("Temperature", TempFac ="\\d+"),
    cols_remove = TRUE
  ) %>% 
  mutate(
    TempFac = factor(
      x = TempFac,
      levels = c(13,18,25),
      labels = c("13","18","25")
    )
    ) %>% 
    rename("Id" = 'Frogspawn sample id') -> frogs_long

frogs_long
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 60 × 3
      Id TempFac  Time
   <dbl> <fct>   <dbl>
 1     1 13         24
 2     2 18         21
 3     3 25         18
 4     4 13         26
 5     5 18         22
 6     6 25         14
 7     7 13         27
 8     8 18         22
 9     9 25         15
10    10 13         27
# ℹ 50 more rows
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
##
frogs_long %>% count(TempFac)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 3 × 2
  TempFac     n
  <fct>   <int>
1 13         20
2 18         20
3 25         20
```


:::
:::




.

## Plotting Data

.




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
##plotting histograms

frogs_long %>% 
  gf_histogram( ~ Time,
              fill = ~TempFac,
              alpha = 0.5) %>% 
  gf_vline(xintercept = ~mean(Time)) %>% 
  gf_labs(
    title = "Histograms of Hatching Time Distributions vs Temperature",
    x = "Hatching Time", y = "Count"
  ) %>%
  gf_text(7 ~ (mean(Time) + 2),
    label = "Overall Mean"
  ) %>%
  gf_refine(guides(fill = guide_legend(title = "Temperature level (°C)")))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
## Its clear to see that eggs hatch faster if the temperature is higher.
```
:::




.




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
## plotting boxplots
gf_boxplot(
  data = frogs_long,
  Time ~ TempFac,
  fill = ~TempFac,
  alpha = 0.5
) %>%
  gf_vline(xintercept = ~ mean(Time)) %>%
  gf_labs(
    title = "Boxplots of Hatching Time Distributions vs Temperature",
    x = "Temperature", y = "Hatching Time",
    caption = "Using ggprism"
  ) %>%
  gf_refine(
    scale_x_discrete(guide = "prism_bracket"),
    guides(fill = guide_legend(title = "Temperature level (°C)"))
  )
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Warning: The S3 guide system was deprecated in ggplot2 3.5.0.
ℹ It has been replaced by a ggproto system that can be extended.
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
## there is very little overlap - both the boxplots and the histograms indicate that temperature has a significant effect on hatching time.
```
:::




.

## Workflow: ANOVA

.




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
frogs_anova <- aov(Time ~ TempFac, data = frogs_long)
##
supernova::pairwise(frogs_anova,
  correction = "Bonferroni", # Try "Tukey"
  alpha = 0.05, # 95% CI calculation
  var_equal = TRUE, # We'll see
  plot = TRUE
)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672}
:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```

```


:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
── Pairwise t-tests with Bonferroni correction ─────────────────────────────────
```


:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Model: Time ~ TempFac
```


:::


::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
TempFac
```


:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Levels: 3
```


:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
Family-wise error-rate: 0.049
```


:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

  group_1 group_2    diff pooled_se       t    df   lower  upper p_adj
  <chr>   <chr>     <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl> <int>   <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>
1 18      13       -5.300     0.257 -20.608    57  -5.861 -4.739 .0000
2 25      13      -10.100     0.257 -39.272    57 -10.661 -9.539 .0000
3 25      18       -4.800     0.257 -18.664    57  -5.361 -4.239 .0000
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
## What is ANOVA doing? It's analyzing the variance...
## Total variance vs var1, var2, var3 --> the difference is so huge.
```
:::
